etymologies: early 16th century; earliest use found in John Skelton (c1460–1529), poet. Origin uncertain; perhaps ultimately showing two or more words of separate origin; perhaps (partly) imitative. Attested earliest in pirling, which in its earliest sense apparently shows sense 3a

definitions: To twist, wind, or spin (threads, fibres, wires, etc.) into cord, braid, net, etc.

notes.text: Apparently unattested in the 17th and 18th centuries.

definitions: To whirl; to revolve rapidly, spin.
To cause to revolve, to spin, roll; to throw or toss with spinning motion.
